Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: Engaging undergraduates in genomic questions and environmental context: Building a database of complex phenotypes for plant knockout mutants
Award.AbstractNarration:
What is the effect of a mutation that "knocks out" a single gene in an organism's genome? Unsatisfyingly, today's plant geneticists can only say: "It depends." Only a small minority of mutations are lethal or have a significant impact. For the vast majority, at most only subtle effects have been detected. Plant genetics is poised to progress rapidly in remedying this situation, using a collection of "knockout" mutant strains of the model species Arabidopsis thaliana. Knockouts, carrying a tiny tagged segment of disruptive DNA in one targeted gene, are already available for ~67% of the 27,000+ unique genes in this plant's genome. Inspired by progress in yeast genetics, the project will grow large subsets of these knockouts in benign and challenging environments, quantifying ecological performance attributes (e.g., population growth rate, fruit yield). We predict that, as in yeast, such an approach will reveal important phenotypic differences between mutant and control lines and possibly reveal undiscovered genome-wide patterns. The project is a collaboration of primarily undergraduate institutions and will train young scientists in how major genomic questions are addressed by networks of researchers.

The project will involve screening 7000 available T-DNA lines to identify those that have mutations at only one gene, providing these results to the biological community. Traits relevant to plant performance will be measured in over 3000 single-mutant lines, across multiple environments. Cyberinfrastructure will be developed to disseminate common protocols and to archive and index data. Over 50 undergraduate researchers will be involved in collecting and analyzing data and communicating results. The project also includes a study of how participating in a distributed research network influences undergraduates' access to social capital within the scientific community. Results from this aspect of the work will lay the foundation for a larger scale, empirical study of the outcomes undergraduates realize by participating in research networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research experiences are thought to be pivotal in the education and professional development of undergraduate science majors. Yet, there are many more undergraduates in the life sciences than can be accommodated through traditional research internships, which involve one-on-one mentoring by faculty members. In order to meet the increasing demand for undergraduate research experiences, faculty are developing and testing new models for scaling up access to research in the life sciences. The purpose of this project was to study one such model, a “networked research experience,” in which teams of undergraduates worked with faculty collaborating in research across multiple institutions. Specifically, we wanted to know whether undergraduates involved in networked research formed influential relationships with faculty or other researchers outside their own institutions and, if so, how these relationships formed and what their impacts were.

In order to accomplish this, we designed and conducted a study that examined how undergraduates gained access to the research network, what their experiences were in the network, and what outcomes they realized as a result of participating in the network. We also measured the relationships they formed within and across the network and determined whether their relationships were correlated with their outcomes. We found that students in the research network realized the same outcomes as students who participate in traditional research internships. This is important because it indicates there is some latitude in how we can design research experiences while ensuring they remain effective for students. We also found there is no unique advantage to participating in networked research. This is most likely because the undergraduates in this network primarily developed strong relationships with other members of their research group, and their connections with faculty and students in research groups at other institutions were not strong enough to be influential.

We also found that undergraduates who participated in this research network were students who had high “science research capital.” In other words, they came into the network with strong prior science learning experiences and they had families where one or both parents had a bachelor’s or graduate degree. These characteristics helped them to stand out in their science classes such that faculty invited them to participate in research, or gave them the knowledge and confidence to approach a faculty member about doing research with them. There is a growing body of research suggesting that research experiences can help students be successful in science, but our results showed that students with low capital wouldn’t get a chance to get involved in the network in the first place.

This result prompted the lead scientists of the network to change how they were recruiting undergraduates such that a broader group of students could get involved. This result also led us to develop a novel survey instrument useful for measuring undergraduates’ science research capital, which we have titled the “science research resource generator.” This instrument is in the final stages of testing and will soon be freely available. We designed the survey to be brief and easy to administer so that it could be used by program staff, administrators, and researchers to test the malleability of undergraduates’ science research capital and to determine the effects of interventions aimed at broadening participation in science, such as science courses that have research experiences embedded in them.
